awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Development of a Distributed Ledger System to Track Environmental Sustainability
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this SBIR Phase I project is to track potential environmental impact in a tamper-proof fashion.  This database can be used for outreach, benchmarking, and other applications.  The forecasts developed can be used to inform strategic resource allocation decisions and other discussions regarding environmental sustainability.  

This project integrates traditional carbon analysis methods, such as Life Cycle Assessment, with distributed ledgers and the internet of things to create a global carbon emission tracking system.  This system will incorporate data from a sensor network measuring air quality, water quality, atmospheric carbon levels, and other variables. This project will conduct design and development of a dynamic system of carbon tracking using blockchain to verify records over time, creating a centralized, tamper-proof record for global carbon emissions. The project will also develop improved models and forecasts on various regional, industrial, and temporal scales.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
For Phase I, Map-Collective developed a blockchain-controlled system of global carbon emissions management. This involves version control to track various additions and subtractions to carbon levels as they occur, over the course of each year, and over the course of decades. During Phase I, the team set out to create the foundation for this system, which would then be tied to the final leg for our annual program for carbon tracking, the CARBON PLAN.

From August 2021 to February 2022, Map-Collective's team developed the foundational elements of a blockchain-controlled system of global carbon emissions management, based in polkadot, and linked to a front-end global carbon map with dashboards for 3 distinct types of users; individuals, governments, and businesses. 

We generated a questionnaire for each of these 3 user types that would allow us to calculate and store the essential carbon footprint information for each user type in their carbon dashboard profile and the associated time-stamped blockchain record.

To provide our users with actionable goals after performing this calculation of a user's baseline year carbon footprint, we created a tentative "negative budget" for how much carbon you should be offsetting or how "negative" you should be, when going beyond "net zero", collectively reversing the damage we have done in accumulating atmospheric CO2. We used the planetary boundaries framework to analyze the feasibility of this, taking into account the current discussion around this framework and its applications so far.

Finally, we documented our processes for GHG calcualtion methodology, blockchain delivery, and the application of the planetary boundaries framework in downloadable attachments on our website.


Last Modified: 12/12/2022
Modified by: Tara O Gupta
